column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.RoleAnnotation|roles
#Text=Mr.
#Text=Wenaweser (Liechtenstein): We thank you,\r
#Text=Mr.
#Text=President, for organizing this debate, and we thank\r
#Text=those who have offered briefings this morning.
#Text=As a\r
#Text=delegation that has supported resolution 1325 (2000) in\r
#Text=its entirety since it was adopted, we agree that progress\r
#Text=towards achieving its major goals has been slow and\r
#Text=uneven.
#Text=That is particularly true with regard to the low\r
#Text=number of women appointed as Special Envoys and the\r
#Text=continuing underrepresentation of women in formal\r
#Text=peace processes and in peacekeeping missions.
#Text=Your\r
#Text=concept paper, Mr.
#Text=President, and the report of the\r
#Text=Secretary-General make it clear that we must\r
#Text=considerably strengthen our efforts in that respect.
#Text=We\r
#Text=hope that the input provided during this debate will\r
#Text=finally, eight years after the adoption of the resolution,\r
#Text=lead to significant improvements.
#Text=Appointing more women to leading positions\r
#Text=would have a catalytic effect and truly empower\r
#Text=women affected by armed conflict.
#Text=It would strengthen\r
#Text=the perception that women are stakeholders 4 as\r
#Text=opposed to mere victims or aid recipients.
#Text=A few years\r
#Text=ago, our then Permanent Representative in New York,\r
#Text=Ambassador Fritsche, headed a group of like-minded\r
#Text=ambassadors that tried to work towards an increase in\r
#Text=the number of women in such positions.
#Text=The group met\r
#Text=regularly to exchange views and met with the\r
#Text=Secretary-General for joint lobbying efforts.
#Text=It was\r
#Text=later taken over by the United Kingdom representative,\r
#Text=Sir Jeremy Greenstock, but their effort was thereafter\r
#Text=discontinued.
#Text=Several years later, it is sad to note that almost no\r
#Text=progress has been made.
#Text=Despite repeated expressions\r
#Text=of good intent from all sides, a single woman currently\r
#Text=serves as Special Representative of the Secretary-\r
#Text=General, and women account for 28 per cent of higher-\r
#Text=category civilian staff in the Department of\r
#Text=Peacekeeping Operations.
#Text=We therefore fully support\r
#Text=and reiterate today the call addressed to the Secretary-\r
#Text=General by the Women's Leaders Working Group to\r
#Text=establish, as a matter of high priority, a mechanism to\r
#Text=increase the number of women in such positions as\r
#Text=United Nations Special Representatives and Envoys, as\r
#Text=well as heads of peace operations.
#Text=Existing programmes to increase the leadership\r
#Text=and peacemaking capacities of women must be further\r
#Text=expanded.
#Text=We also believe that the creation of a gender\r
#Text=unit within the Department of Peacekeeping Operations\r
#Text=would contribute to that goal.
#Text=With the adoption this\r
#Text=year of Presidential No.
#Text=Statement 36, the Security\r
#Text=Council noted that women have an important role to\r
#Text=play in mediation and the settlement of disputes.
#Text=In\r
#Text=particular at the grass-roots level, their role can be\r
#Text=significantly more important than that of men.
#Text=The\r
#Text=Council must therefore institutionalize women's equal\r
#Text=and substantive participation at all levels of peace\r
#Text=processes and create mechanisms to monitor their\r
#Text=equal participation systematically.
#Text=There is a clear link between an increase in\r
#Text=women's participation in peacekeeping missions and\r
#Text=the potentially lower level of sexual violence in\r
#Text=conflict and post-conflict situations.
#Text=Since girls and\r
#Text=women in affected regions often associate uniformed\r
#Text=personnel with sexual violence, a higher number of\r
#Text=women participating in peacekeeping and police forces\r
#Text=will dramatically enhance the access of victims to\r
#Text=social and psychological services, including trauma\r
#Text=counselling and information-sharing on sexual\r
#Text=harassment, abuse and rape.
#Text=Most importantly, of course, those who are\r
#Text=supposed to provide protection must not, under any\r
#Text=circumstances, themselves become perpetrators.
#Text=All\r
#Text=acts of sexual violence committed by peacekeeping\r
#Text=personnel, including sexual exploitation and child\r
#Text=prostitution, are unacceptable.
#Text=They heavily undermine\r
#Text=the credibility and effectiveness of any peace\r
#Text=operation, but also of the Organization as a whole.
#Text=Zero tolerance can therefore be the only policy in that\r
#Text=respect.
#Text=The ultimate goal must be that the attitude and\r
#Text=behaviour of peacekeepers towards women can serve\r
#Text=as a model for local communities.
#Text=Furthermore, the\r
#Text=mandates of peacekeeping missions must provide clear\r
#Text=guidance, especially for commanders, on how to\r
#Text=protect civilians, in particular girls and women, from\r
#Text=sexual violence.
#Text=Predeployment and on-mission\r
#Text=30\r
#Text=training programmes must instruct police, security and\r
#Text=humanitarian personnel on how to recognize and react\r
#Text=to incidents of sexual violence.
#Text=Sexual violence is one of the most important\r
#Text=aspects of resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=While it has always\r
#Text=been part of armed conflicts, its systematic and\r
#Text=targeted use in numerous situations today is not just a\r
#Text=by-product of hostilities, or even just a war crime as\r
#Text=recognized in the Rome Statute.
#Text=It often is a method of\r
#Text=warfare that aims to destroy the social fabric of\r
#Text=communities in order to achieve political and military\r
#Text=ends.
#Text=It is against that background that we\r
#Text=co-sponsored resolution 1820 (2008) on the protection\r
#Text=of civilians from all forms of sexual violence.
#Text=We also welcome the adoption of presidential\r
#Text=statement 2008/28 on children in armed conflict,\r
#Text=referring to resolution 1820 (2008), and repeat our call\r
#Text=for targeted sanctions against perpetrators of acts of\r
#Text=sexual violence.
